title: Sutton in Craven and Lund's Tower Walk Route

images.title: al partington / Bay Horse, Sutton in Craven
images.caption: Bay Horse, Sutton in Craven

images.title: Betty Longbottom / Sutton Park
images.caption: Sutton Park. An attractive park in the village.

images.title: Humphrey Bolton / Gateway to Lund's Tower, Sutton
images.caption: Gateway to Lund's Tower. A custom-made kissing gate with the initials LTS, which I think stands for Lund's Tower Society.

images.title: Gordon Hatton / Earl Crag and Wainman's Pinnacle
images.caption: Earl Crag and Wainman's Pinnacle. The gritstone outcrop of Earl Crag with the monument Pinnacle on the highest point. Wainman’s Pinnacle was built in 1898 as a memorial to the Napoleonic Wars by a man known as Wainman

images.title: Humphrey Bolton / Pond at Earl Crag, Sutton
images.caption: Pond at Earl Crag. Presumably there must be a layer of clay to hold the water so near to a rocky edge.

images.title: Humphrey Bolton / Footpath to Lund's Tower, Sutton
images.caption: Footpath to Lund's Tower, Sutton

description: This North Yorkshire based village is located near Keighley and Skipton in the Craven District of the county. This walk from the village takes you up to Wainman's Pinnacle and Lund's Tower, a folly and viewpoint located just south west of the settlement. You can start the walk in the village at Sutton Park, a delightful local park with green lawns and flower beds. From near here you can pick up footpaths heading south west through the countryside to the tower. The monument was built by James Lund, the the son of William Lund, the owner a large textile manufacturing business. It is thought to have been constructed either to celebrate the birth of Lund's daughter Ethel or to commemorate the 1887 jubilee of Queen Victoria. The route then continues to Wainman's Pinnacle which lies just to the west of Lund's tower. The monument stands on Earl Crag at a height of 354 metres. The two neighbouring towers are often referred to as the Salt and Pepper Pots.

details.subtitle: Further Information and Other Local Ideas
details.content: Just to the north you can pick up the Leeds and Liverpool Canal and enjoy a stroll along the towpath into neighbouring Silsden. To the north west is Lothersdale where you can enjoy a climb to Pinhaw Beacon for some excellent views of the area. The village also includes a historic pub worthy of some investigation.

display_address: Gatering Lane, Sutton, North Yorkshire, York and North Yorkshire, England, BD20 7NY, United Kingdom
